author: Today I Found Out
description:
In a typical 19th century city, the buildings were not exactly the skyscrapers we associate with cities today, and mostly made of wood. Asphalt was missing entirely from the streets, the clothing was hand-crafted and aesthetic in its own right, the store fronts proclaimed all sorts of fancy products that are now either commonplace or far outdated, and - encompassing everything - the spirit of enterprise and emerging modernity hung in the air. Cities were growing rapidly to give homes, work and purpose to millions. 

The sheer mass of people also brought with it an incredible level of noise, as attested by philosopher Arthur Schoppenhauer, who wrote an entire enraged treatise on the habit of cracking whips all day. Then there was the smell. The unbearable, unignorable smell, not only of people living in cramped quarters, but most importantly of feces scattered throughout the streets. 

Naturally this whole situation was not only a hindrance to progress, but also dangerous, as this lack
title: That Time the Entire City of Chicago was Raised about Ten Feet for Reasons
